She was right.  But the persuasion that follows (i.e., "therefore don't=
 bother with unit tests"), is like saying "We all die someday, so we might =
as well live like there's no tomorrow."

> Instead, she performed specifica=
cion checking using

I laughed=
 when I saw "theorem provers."  I've never met a hands-on professional in t=
he software industry (and maybe your colleague was just in a different indu=
stry, even if she developed software) who would even think of theorem prove=
r as a solution for a QA problem at work (unless maybe the problem had to d=
o with testing theorems, which isn't often in the business world).

Advance=
d tools (by which I project you mean source metrics, UI automation, coverag=
e analysis) are great, but they usually cost money and most people, even so=
-called professionals, are too stupid, overworked, cheap or lazy to use the=
m effectively, if at all.  Those who do know these tools are hard to find a=
nd expensive to hire.  By all means, use them whenever you can, though.  A =
rare individual will use these kinds of tools effectively and drive major c=
hanges through an engineering and/or QA team.  But even then, that person a=
nd the effectiveness of the tools are like the center of rippling circles i=
n a pond -- they diminish as they move out from center.

> This has made me=
 think

ty

s? Could it have an impact on unit

No, not a bit.  There's been plenty of research and writing on the effecti=
veness of different tools, metrics and test techniques.  See anything by Bo=
ris Beizer, Glenford Myers, or Robert Binder (anyone can get books by these=
 guys on Amazon).  Unit testing is one of many techniques, and is generally=
 regarded as a sine qua non of quality code and development methodology.  B=
ut it's no silver bullet.

Basically, you tossed up a real softball questio=
n.  I wouldn't mind discussing it, but would rather hear some more specific=
, detailed arguments, ideally supported by literature rather than just an a=
necdote.
